climbs.name: Stabbing Westward
climbs.fa: Brad Singer, Dave Honeywell, David LePere 11/00

content.description:
A few moves up a right-facing corner off the ground leads to the base of a slab with one bolt. Crux moves past the bolt lead to easier climbing following a thin crack to the top.

The guide calls this route 5.10b; it seemed a little easier than that.

Great rock and good moves make this probably the best route on the crag.
content.protection: In addition to the lone bolt, cams up to a #3 Camalot can be used, with the emphasis on small sizes.
content.location: In the middle of the N.E. face of Blackhawk Pinnacle. Look for the single bolt on a slabby section of rock.

content.description:
A striking right-leaning thin/tips crack that splits a shield of clean rock.

Short but technical and demanding.
content.location: Located high on the west face of the crag. A bit of scrambling is necessary to gain the base of the route.

climbs.name: Silver
climbs.fa: Pat Brennan and Brad Singer, November 1998

content.description: Starts in a recessed area and pulls a small roof down low before transitioning into a lower angled left-facing corner.
content.location: Between Stabbing Westward and Blackhawk ArÃªte.

content.description: Crux moves up a crack at the start lead to an easy right-facing corner/ramp, then fun, steep moves with good holds at the top.
content.protection: Stoppers and cams up to #3 Camalot
content.location: Farthest right route on the N.E. Face. Start just right of the obvious bolted arete route (Blackhawk Arete).

climbs.name: Grapevine
climbs.fa: Pat Brennan and Brad Singer, November 1998

content.description: A vertical hand crack leads to a Y at two-thirds height with two cracks above; finish in either the left or right crack at roughly the same difficulty.
content.location: Far left side of the north face.

climbs.name: Cactus
climbs.fa: Brad Singer and Pat Brennan, November 1998

content.description: A thin hand crack down low leads into a low angled right-facing corner.

climbs.name: Blackhawk Arete
climbs.fa: Brad Singer, Steve Kravchuck, Dave Honeywell, David Lepere 11/00

content.description: On the right side of the N.E. face follow four bolts up the obvious arete. Pulling directly past the overhang at the bottom is 5.10b; this can be easily avoided ny climbing the bottom of Panamint Annie and stepping back left onto the arete, making the route 5.8 or 5.9. The rock on the arete itself is very nice smooth granite.
content.protection: Four bolts on the arete. Some gear could be placed at the bottom to protect the moves to the first bolt. Two-bolt anchor at top.
content.location: Obvious bolted arete on right side of N.E. face.
